title: Difference in error mentioned in the book vs running the program

labels.name: A-docs
labels.description: Area: documentation for any part of the project, including the compiler, standard library, and tools

body:
Running a small Rust snippet from "The Rust Programming Language" Book


https://doc.rust-lang.org/book/second-edition/ch03-03-how-functions-work.html

As per docs the following error is expected

Running this code produces an error, as follows:

```
error[E0308]: mismatched types
--> src/main.rs:7:28
  |
7 |   fn plus_one(x: i32) -> i32 {
  |  ____________________________^
8 | |     x + 1;
9 | | }
  | |_^ expected i32, found ()                     <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
  |
  = note: expected type `i32`                      <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
             found type `()`
help: consider removing this semicolon:
--> src/main.rs:8:10
  |
8 |     x + 1;
  |
```


Actually running this on the system, notice how the "expected" is reversed
In the Book example it says "expect i32, found()" which is correct
Whereas on the system the error says "expected (), found i32" which is wrong


```
error[E0308]: mismatched types
--> src/main.rs:6:28
  |
6 |   fn plus_one(x: i32) -> i32 {
  |  ____________________________^
7 | |     x + 1;
8 | | }
  | |_^ expected (), found i32                                                                      <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
  |
  = note: expected type `()`                                                                          <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
             found type `i32`
help: consider removing this semicolon:
--> src/main.rs:7:10
  |
7 |     x + 1;
  |          ^
```


Version Information
=============

rustc --version
rustc 1.18.0 (03fc9d622 2017-06-06)

cargo --version
cargo 0.19.0 (28d1d60d4 2017-05-16)
